articles.title: UK and US unveil nuclear energy deal promising thousands of jobs
articles.summary: Key among the plans is a proposal to build up to 12 advanced modular nuclear reactors in Hartlepool.
articles.content:
UK and US unveil nuclear energy deal promising thousands of jobs

5 hours ago Share Save Charlotte Edwards Business reporter, BBC News Share Save

Getty Images

The UK and US are set to sign a landmark agreement aimed at accelerating the development of nuclear power. The move is expected to generate thousands of jobs and strengthen Britain's energy security. It is expected to be signed off during US President Donald Trump's state visit this week, with both sides hoping it will unlock billions in private investment. Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said the two nations were "building a golden age of nuclear" that would put them at the "forefront of global innovation".

The government has said that generating more power from nuclear can cut household energy bills, create jobs, boost energy security, and tackle climate change. The new agreement, known as the Atlantic Partnership for Advanced Nuclear Energy, aims to make it quicker for companies to build new nuclear power stations in both the UK and the US. It will streamline regulatory approvals, cutting the average licensing period for nuclear projects from up to four years to just two.

'Nuclear renaissance'

The deal is also aimed at increasing commercial partnerships between British and American companies, with a number of deals set to be announced. Key among the plans is a proposal from US nuclear group X-Energy and UK energy company Centrica to build up to 12 advanced modular nuclear reactors in Hartlepool, with the potential to power 1.5 million homes and create up to 2,500 jobs. The broader programme could be worth up to £40bn, with £12bn focused in the north east of England. Other plans include multinational firms such as Last Energy and DP World working together on a micro modular reactor at London Gateway port. This is backed by £80m in private investment. Elsewhere, Holtec, EDF and Tritax are also planning to repurpose the former Cottam coal-fired plant in Nottinghamshire into a nuclear-powered data centre hub. This project is estimated to be worth £11bn and could create thousands of high-skilled construction jobs, as well as permanent jobs in long-term operations. Beyond power generation, the new partnership includes collaboration on fusion energy research, and an end to UK and US reliance on Russian nuclear material by 2028.

Commenting on the agreement, Energy Secretary Ed Miliband said: "Nuclear will power our homes with clean, homegrown energy and the private sector is building it in Britain, delivering growth and well-paid, skilled jobs for working people." And US Energy Secretary Chris Wright described the move as a "nuclear renaissance", saying it would enhance energy security and meet growing global power demands, particularly from AI and data infrastructure.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant bilateral agreement between the UK and US to accelerate nuclear energy development, promising large-scale job creation, enhanced energy security, and contributions to tackling climate change. It includes concrete plans for advanced modular reactors and fusion research, with substantial private investment and broad societal benefits.
articles.personality_title: UK and US join forces to boost nuclear energy and create thousands of jobs
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The UK and the US want to work together to build more nuclear power plants. This comes as both countries look for ways to make energy cheaper, safer, and cleaner.

**What happened** – The two countries agreed on a new deal called the Atlantic Partnership for Advanced Nuclear Energy. It was announced during the US President’s visit to the UK. The deal will help build up to 12 new small nuclear reactors in Hartlepool, England, which could power 1.5 million homes and create about 2,500 jobs. Companies from both countries will also work on other projects, like turning an old coal plant into a nuclear-powered data center and developing fusion energy.

**Impact** – This agreement is important because it will speed up how quickly nuclear power plants get approved and built, cutting the usual wait time in half. It will bring billions of pounds in private investment, create many skilled jobs, and reduce reliance on energy from other countries. Using more nuclear energy can also help lower household energy bills and reduce pollution.

**What's next step** – The UK and US will start working on the new reactors and other projects soon. They will also keep researching fusion energy, a new kind of power that could be even cleaner. The goal is to stop depending on Russian nuclear materials by 2028.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UK and US have launched a major partnership to build new nuclear power plants, create thousands of jobs, and strengthen clean energy for the future.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Royaume-Uni et les États-Unis s’unissent pour développer l’énergie nucléaire et créer des milliers d’emplois
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Royaume-Uni et les États-Unis souhaitent collaborer pour construire davantage de centrales nucléaires. Cela intervient alors que les deux pays cherchent à rendre l’énergie moins chère, plus sûre et plus propre.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Les deux pays ont conclu un nouvel accord appelé le Partenariat Atlantique pour l’Énergie Nucléaire Avancée. Il a été annoncé lors de la visite du président américain au Royaume-Uni. Cet accord permettra de construire jusqu’à 12 petits réacteurs nucléaires à Hartlepool, en Angleterre, capables d’alimenter 1,5 million de foyers et de créer environ 2 500 emplois. Des entreprises des deux pays travailleront aussi sur d’autres projets, comme la transformation d’une ancienne centrale à charbon en centre de données nucléaire et le développement de l’énergie de fusion.

**Impact** – Cet accord est important car il accélérera la construction et l’approbation des centrales nucléaires, réduisant de moitié les délais habituels. Il apportera des milliards de livres d’investissements privés, créera de nombreux emplois qualifiés et réduira la dépendance énergétique extérieure. L’utilisation accrue de l’énergie nucléaire peut aussi faire baisser les factures d’électricité et réduire la pollution.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Royaume-Uni et les États-Unis vont bientôt commencer à travailler sur les nouveaux réacteurs et autres projets. Ils poursuivront aussi la recherche sur l’énergie de fusion, une source d’énergie encore plus propre. L’objectif est de ne plus dépendre du combustible nucléaire russe d’ici 2028.

**Une phrase clé** – Le Royaume-Uni et les États-Unis ont lancé un partenariat majeur pour construire de nouvelles centrales nucléaires, créer des milliers d’emplois et renforcer une énergie propre pour l’avenir.
articles.personality_title_es: Reino Unido y EE. UU. se unen para impulsar la energía nuclear y crear miles de empleos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Reino Unido y Estados Unidos quieren trabajar juntos para construir más plantas de energía nuclear. Esto ocurre mientras ambos países buscan formas de hacer que la energía sea más barata, segura y limpia.

**Qué pasó** – Los dos países acordaron un nuevo pacto llamado Asociación Atlántica para la Energía Nuclear Avanzada. Se anunció durante la visita del presidente de EE. UU. al Reino Unido. El acuerdo ayudará a construir hasta 12 pequeños reactores nucleares en Hartlepool, Inglaterra, que podrían abastecer a 1.5 millones de hogares y crear alrededor de 2,500 empleos. Empresas de ambos países también trabajarán en otros proyectos, como convertir una planta de carbón antigua en un centro de datos nuclear y desarrollar energía de fusión.

**Impacto** – Este acuerdo es importante porque acelerará el proceso para aprobar y construir plantas nucleares, reduciendo a la mitad el tiempo de espera habitual. Traerá miles de millones de libras en inversión privada, creará muchos empleos calificados y reducirá la dependencia energética extranjera. Usar más energía nuclear también puede ayudar a bajar las facturas de electricidad y a reducir la contaminación.

**Próximo paso** – Reino Unido y EE. UU. comenzarán pronto a trabajar en los nuevos reactores y otros proyectos. También seguirán investigando la energía de fusión, una fuente de energía aún más limpia. La meta es dejar de depender del material nuclear ruso para 2028.

**Resumen en una frase** – Reino Unido y EE. UU. iniciaron una gran alianza para construir nuevas plantas nucleares, crear miles de empleos y fortalecer la energía limpia para el futuro.

articles.title: Exploring the informal plastic waste recycling industry in Yaounde, Cameroon
articles.summary: Cameroon's informal waste collection workers have come to play a crucial role in supplementing the country's official waste processing industry; however, the work doesn't come without its risks and drawbacks.
articles.content:
With the rise in plastic usage and a growing population, Cameroon's waste processing industry is struggling to keep up with the increasing demand. This has given rise to an informal waste processing sector where children, teens, and older individuals are making a living by sorting through household waste, dumpsters, and landfills and collecting plastic waste for recycling companies.

Cameroon has a population of over 29 million people, with approximately 3.3 million inhabitants in Yaoundé, the country's political capital and one of its largest cities. According to a report published by Landfillsolutions, the nation produces an estimated 600,000 tons of plastic waste annually. This includes plastic bottles, bags, food packaging, furniture, plastic pipes, toys, and more.

Despite numerous recycling initiatives by the government and private stakeholders nationwide, there is not enough formal capacity to meet the city's waste demand and a significant amount of waste continues to flood the streets of Yaoundé daily, causing a range of negative environmental and health impacts.

Of the millions of tons of plastic waste produced each year, less than 10 percent can be recycled, leaving more than half to be dumped in landfills while the remainder is littered along roads, in bodies of water, or incinerated. This practice can lead to land pollution and poisoning, suffocates aquatic ecosystems, and contributes to ozone layer depletion.

Amid efforts to reduce plastic waste, a collaboration has emerged between individuals and private recycling enterprises in Yaoundé, where individuals transport household waste from people's homes to dumpsters and from dumpsters to recyclers. Children, teens, and even older individuals play various roles at each stage.

Hearing the phrase “vider poubelle,” which translates from French to “empty your bin,” daily in neighborhoods like Obili, Ngoa-Ekele, and Biyem-Assi in Yaoundé is commonplace. Teenagers walk the streets yelling this phrase to alert people that they've arrived to collect their trash. The kids charge between FCFA 50 and 500 (USD 0.09–89), depending on the amount of waste. These children recount that they can reach about eleven households a day when the weather is favorable. They also say they engage in this activity to earn an income to help support their households.

The dumpster search

When household waste is emptied at major trash can points in the city, others scout these areas day in and day out for recyclables amidst a sea of waste. Romeo Toukan Fotso, a waste collector, recounts to Global Voices:

I run a team with four other people; we search dumpsters and gutters around the Yaoundé VI municipality for valuable plastic waste.

After spending over a year in this work, he states that it helps him meet his needs. He adds:

We work with two recycling companies, NAMé Recycling and Eco Green. They offer FCFA 50 (USD 0.09) per kilogram of plastic waste. My team and I collect up to 200 kg per day and pile it up until Saturday when we take it to the recyclers.

Dumpster searchers say they spend between 10 to 12 hours daily in pursuit of valuable items. According to them, the long hours can occasionally lead to a pricy payoff, so they leave no stone unturned.

Marc Monkam, Regional Director for NAMé Recycling — an enterprise dedicated to monetizing plastic waste, explained that they have established a network of independent collectors who sign an agreement that grants them the status of “NAMé collector.” He told Global Voices:

Each collector assigned is in charge of picking up plastic waste in a particular area, with some of them making up to FCFA 120,000 (USD 212) a week.

He adds that the collected plastic waste undergoes a treatment process and is transformed into two finished products: strapping rolls from PET(Polyethylene Terephthalate) plastic, which are used to stabilize goods like logs of wood, for easy transportation. Another finished product includes heavy-duty plastic pallets made from HDPE (High-Density Polyethylene) plastic, which are used in logistics industries. He says:

We also encourage households to get more involved in this recycling process, by practicing source separation. This will add more value to the waste, as separated materials will not contaminate each other.

These informal workers have come to play a crucial role in supplementing the country's formal waste processing industry; however, the work doesn't come without its risks and drawbacks.

Negative health effects

Various health risks arise over time from this industry, as more than half of those scouting for plastics in dumpsters do not wear protective gear or facemasks. They spend hours inhaling pungent odors caused by both natural and chemically induced processes. Health experts warn that this can lead to severe respiratory and gastrointestinal infections while increasing the risk of contracting airborne diseases like cholera. Many who venture into this line of work without precautions report consuming locally cooked herbs called “soukoudai” or drinking four to five tins of unsweetened evaporated (Peak) milk weekly to boost their immune system. However, Erica Nenyoh, a Medical Laboratory Technician at the Jomarfor Health Clinic in the South West Region of Cameroon, states:

There is no scientific study that proves consuming ‘Peak’ milk can enhance the immune system, especially with frequent exposure to pathogens like bacteria, viruses, and parasites.

A blog by the American Lung Association has revealed that waste pickers exposed to plastic fibers can experience lung problems and reduced lung capacity over time. Experts recommend wearing face masks and gloves to avoid direct contact with waste and prevent respiratory issues.

In Cameroon, a joint ministerial decree signed by the Ministries of the Environment and Commerce in 2012 prohibited the production, importation, possession, commercialization, and free distribution of non-biodegradable plastics with a density equal to or less than 60 microns in thickness. This is because such plastics are lighter, cannot be recycled, and can easily pollute the earth. Violators of this law face imprisonment of two to ten years and a fine of FCFA 11.2 million (USD 20,000).

With a rapidly growing population and increase in plastic use, a more sustainable means of preserving ecosystems has emerged through recycling. Conscious citizens do their part by cleaning the environment, properly managing their waste, collecting plastics for recycling while awaiting the government to renew regulations and reduce plastic consumption nationwide.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the significant positive impact of the informal plastic waste recycling sector in Yaoundé, Cameroon, which supplements formal waste management efforts and helps reduce environmental pollution. It provides detailed context on the scope of plastic waste challenges, the role of informal workers, and the recycling process that transforms waste into useful products. Despite health risks, the story underscores community-driven environmental action and ongoing policy efforts, making it a meaningful and inspiring example of grassroots environmental sustainability with broad societal relevance.
articles.personality_title: Informal plastic recycling helps reduce waste in Yaoundé, Cameroon
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Cameroon faces a growing problem with plastic waste, producing about 600,000 tons each year. Yaoundé, the capital city, has over 3 million people, and its official waste management cannot keep up with all the plastic trash produced daily.

**What happened**
Because formal recycling cannot handle all the waste, many people—including children and teenagers—collect plastic from homes, dumpsters, and landfills. They sell this plastic to companies like NAMé Recycling and Eco Green. These companies turn the plastic into useful products such as strong straps and plastic pallets used in shipping. Collectors can earn money by gathering plastic, sometimes making up to $200 a week.

**Impact**
This informal recycling helps reduce plastic pollution on streets and in the environment. It also creates jobs for many people who might not have other work options. However, the job has health risks because many collectors do not use protective gear and are exposed to harmful substances. Despite these challenges, this grassroots effort plays an important role in supporting the city’s waste management.

**What's next step**
Recycling companies encourage people to separate their waste at home to make recycling easier and more effective. The government has laws to reduce harmful plastics and plans to improve waste policies. Continued cooperation between informal collectors, recycling businesses, and the government will be important to manage plastic waste better in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Informal plastic waste collectors in Yaoundé help reduce pollution and create jobs, showing how community efforts support recycling even when formal systems are limited.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le recyclage informel du plastique réduit les déchets à Yaoundé, Cameroun
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le Cameroun produit environ 600 000 tonnes de déchets plastiques chaque année. Yaoundé, la capitale, compte plus de 3 millions d’habitants, et la gestion officielle des déchets ne peut pas gérer tous ces déchets plastiques produits quotidiennement.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Comme le recyclage formel ne peut pas traiter tous les déchets, beaucoup de personnes—y compris des enfants et des adolescents—collectent le plastique chez les habitants, dans les poubelles et les décharges. Ils vendent ce plastique à des entreprises comme NAMé Recycling et Eco Green, qui le transforment en produits utiles comme des sangles solides et des palettes en plastique utilisées pour le transport. Les collecteurs peuvent gagner de l’argent, parfois jusqu’à 200 dollars par semaine.

**Impact**
Ce recyclage informel aide à réduire la pollution plastique dans les rues et l’environnement. Il crée aussi des emplois pour des personnes qui n’en auraient pas autrement. Cependant, ce travail comporte des risques pour la santé car beaucoup ne portent pas d’équipement de protection et sont exposés à des substances dangereuses. Malgré cela, cet effort local joue un rôle important pour soutenir la gestion des déchets de la ville.

**Prochaine étape**
Les entreprises de recyclage encouragent les habitants à trier leurs déchets chez eux pour faciliter et améliorer le recyclage. Le gouvernement a des lois pour réduire les plastiques nocifs et prévoit d’améliorer les politiques sur les déchets. La coopération continue entre collecteurs informels, entreprises de recyclage et gouvernement sera importante pour mieux gérer les déchets plastiques.

**Phrase clé**
Les collecteurs informels de déchets plastiques à Yaoundé aident à réduire la pollution et à créer des emplois, montrant comment les efforts communautaires soutiennent le recyclage malgré des systèmes formels limités.
articles.personality_title_es: El reciclaje informal de plástico ayuda a reducir residuos en Yaundé, Camerún
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Camerún produce alrededor de 600,000 toneladas de desechos plásticos cada año. Yaundé, la capital, tiene más de 3 millones de habitantes, y la gestión oficial de residuos no puede manejar toda la basura plástica diaria.

**Qué pasó**
Como el reciclaje formal no puede procesar todos los desechos, muchas personas—incluidos niños y adolescentes—recogen plástico de casas, contenedores y vertederos. Venden este plástico a empresas como NAMé Recycling y Eco Green, que lo transforman en productos útiles como correas resistentes y pallets de plástico usados en transporte. Los recolectores pueden ganar dinero, a veces hasta 200 dólares por semana.

**Impacto**
Este reciclaje informal ayuda a reducir la contaminación por plástico en las calles y el medio ambiente. También crea empleos para personas que de otro modo no tendrían trabajo. Sin embargo, el trabajo tiene riesgos de salud porque muchos no usan equipo de protección y están expuestos a sustancias dañinas. A pesar de esto, este esfuerzo comunitario juega un papel importante en apoyar la gestión de residuos de la ciudad.

**Próximo paso**
Las empresas de reciclaje animan a la gente a separar sus residuos en casa para facilitar y mejorar el reciclaje. El gobierno tiene leyes para reducir los plásticos dañinos y planea mejorar las políticas de residuos. La cooperación continua entre recolectores informales, empresas de reciclaje y el gobierno será clave para manejar mejor los residuos plásticos.

**Frase clave**
Los recolectores informales de plástico en Yaundé ayudan a reducir la contaminación y crear empleos, mostrando cómo los esfuerzos comunitarios apoyan el reciclaje cuando los sistemas formales son limitados.
